Legal_Issue: Whether the Canadian Human Rights Commission's decision to dismiss the complaint under section 41(1)(d) of the Canadian Human Rights Act was reasonable and procedurally fair
Evidence_Assessment: No evidence of discriminatory practices found
Burden_of_Proof: On the applicant to demonstrate discriminatory practice
Credibility_Factor: Complaint deemed vexatious and made in bad faith
Legal_Rule: A complaint must constitute a discriminatory practice under sections 5 to 14.1 of the Canadian Human Rights Act; section 41(1)(d) allows dismissal if trivial, frivolous, vexatious, or made in bad faith
Procedural_Issue: Procedural fairness of the Commission's dismissal
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged racial discrimination in non-renewal or termination of maintenance contracts
Procedural_Fairness_Assessment: Decision found to be procedurally fair
Key_Evidence_Considered: Nature of contract termination, absence of connection to prohibited grounds of discrimination
Legal_Framework: Federal Courts Act, Canadian Human Rights Act
Applicant_Challenge: Challenge to Commission's dismissal of complaint
Court_Result: Federal Court dismissed the judicial review application
Legal_Rule_Source: Sections 5 to 14.1 and 41(1)(d) of the Canadian Human Rights Act
Defendant_Response: Non-renewal based on operational or contractual reasons, not discriminatory intent
Evidence_Type: Documentary and contextual evidence regarding contract management
Resolution_Mechanism: Administrative review followed by judicial review
Legal_Provision: Section 41(1)(d) of the Canadian Human Rights Act
Authority: Canadian Human Rights Commission, Federal Court
Claimant_Status: Complainant before the Canadian Human Rights Commission
Grounds_for_Inadmissibility_or_Allegatio: Complaint trivial, frivolous, vexatious, or made in bad faith
Applicable_Process: Complaint investigation and dismissal under the Canadian Human Rights Act
Governing_Rule: Canadian Human Rights Act, Federal Courts Act
